courseTitle: Fundamentals of Human Growth and Development: Birth through Adolescence
courseDescription: This course contributes to an understanding of the physical, social, emotional, speech and language, and intellectual development of infants, toddlers, children, and adolescents. Furthermore, it promotes the ability to use this understanding in guiding learning experiences and relating meaningfully to preK-12, special education, and secondary education students. The interaction of infants, toddlers, children, and adolescents with economic, social, racial, ethnic, religious, physical, and intellectual differences is explored, as well as developmental issues related to giftedness or disability and the impact of family disruptions, child abuse, and substance abuse.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of physical, social, emotional, speech and language, and intellectual development
Knowledge of developmental issues related to giftedness or disability
Understanding the impact of family disruptions, child abuse, and substance abuse
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to relate meaningfully to preK-12, special education, and secondary education students
Understanding and managing interactions of infants, toddlers, children, and adolescents with various socioeconomic, racial, ethnic, religious, physical, and intellectual differences
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to use understanding of human development in guiding learning experiences
Analyzing the impact of various factors on human development
Evaluating developmental issues related to giftedness or disability
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Guiding learning experiences for individuals of different development stages

courseTitle: Foundations of Special Education: Legal Aspects and Characteristics
courseDescription: The course provides an introduction and overview of the field of special education from the perspective that it is a subsection of general education and that the field is in transition by virtue of philosophical, legislative, and programmatic changes.  Legal aspects, regulatory requirements, and critical analyses of research are addressed. The course includes a broad overview of the characteristics, identification, instructional needs, and accommodation necessary for creating appropriate educational and vocational environments for students with disabilities.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of special education legislative and regulatory requirements
Knowledge of research analysis in special education
Familiarity with educational and vocational accommodations for students with disabilities
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate effectively with students with disabilities
Skills in advocating for the needs of students with disabilities
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing and interpreting special education laws and regulations
Identification of characteristics and instructional needs of students with disabilities
Critical analysis of research in special education
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading educational and vocational planning for students with disabilities
Implementing programmatic changes in special education

courseTitle: Instructional Design I: Learner Characteristics and Assessment
courseDescription: The intent of this course is to provide pre-service and in-service teachers with: (a) knowledge of the characteristics of K-12 students with learning differences who are accessing either the general curriculum or the adapted curriculum, and (b) the ability to develop knowledge and skill in the selection, administration, scoring and interpretation of standardized/norm-referenced and criterion-referenced assessments for exceptional learners. Administering formal and informal assessment tools for the development of an IEP are emphasized. The use of assessment data to improve evidence-based instruction and student performance is discussed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Administration of standardized/norm-referenced and criterion-referenced assessments
Use of assessment tools for IEP development
Interpretation of assessment data for instruction improvement
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and accommodating learning differences in K-12 students
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Selection of appropriate assessment tools
Scoring of diverse assessments
Analyzing assessment data to improve student performance

courseTitle: Directed Field Experience in Special Education
courseDescription: This course provides variable hours of direct participation in a community or educational setting with individuals with special needs.  The course includes specific skills of program planning, implementation, evaluation and classroom management. Practicum of 45 hours required.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Direct communication with individuals with special needs
Collaboration with community or educational setting
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Needs assessment
Program evaluation
Issue resolution in a special education setting
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Project management in a special education setting
Leadership in community or educational environment

courseTitle: Characteristics and Medical Aspects of Disabling Conditions
courseDescription: This course reviews medical conditions present among individuals with disabilities and implications for classroom instruction.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting instructional strategies
Analyzing individual learning needs
Problem-solving for special education

courseTitle: Students with Diverse Learning Needs in the General Education Classroom
courseDescription: This course introduces general education teachers to the legal aspects and educational needs of at-risk students and those with disabilities.  Emphasis is on characteristics of children with special needs and procedures for effective academic, behavioral, and social integration of these children in the general education classroom.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of the legal aspects of education
Knowledge of educational needs of at-risk students and those with disabilities
Familiarity with procedures for effective academic, behavioral, and social integration of special needs children
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with students of diverse learning needs
Ability to communicate legal and educational requirements to staff and parents
Empathy and understanding for students with special needs
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to identify and address academic and behavioral issues
Analytical skills to assess the effectiveness of integration strategies
Problem-solving skills to adapt and optimize procedures for diverse student needs
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in implementing and maintaining inclusive classroom environments
Organizational skills to manage diverse learning needs within a single classroom
Ability to lead and guide staff in supporting students with special needs

courseTitle: Classroom and Behavioral Management Techniques for Students with Diverse Needs
courseDescription: This course addresses classroom management techniques and individual interventions based upon behavioral, cognitive, affective, social, and ecological theory and practice. The course focuses on the field of applied behavior analysis, including best practices in the areas of data collection, program selection, program implementation, and data analysis. Positive behavior management, supports, and functional behavioral assessment for students with diverse learning needs will be emphasized.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Adapting communication for students with diverse learning needs
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Behavioral intervention planning
Functional behavioral assessment
Analyzing behavioral patterns
Cognitive and affective theory application

courseTitle: Instructional Design II: Curricular Procedures and Individualized Education Planning
courseDescription: The intent of this course is to provide preservice and in-service teachers with: (a) knowledge of research-based instruction for PreK-12 students with disabilities and those who are gifted; (b) knowledge and skill in using data collection to make decisions about student progress, instruction, program, accommodations and teaching methodology for exceptional learners, and (c) knowledge and skill in planning, developing and implementing individual educational plans and group instruction for diverse exceptional learners who are accessing the general education curriculum and the standards of learning or the adapted education curriculum and the aligned or essentialized standards of learning.
Technical and Digital Skills: Data collection and analysis for student progress
Planning and implementing individual educational plans
Developing group instruction for diverse exceptional learners
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interacting with PreK-12 students with disabilities and gifted learners
Communicating teaching methodology for exceptional learners
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Making decisions about instruction and program based on data analysis
Adapting teaching methodology for exceptional learners based on individual educational plans
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing instruction program for PreK-12 students
Leading the implementation of individual and group instruction for diverse learners

courseTitle: Collaboration and Transitions
courseDescription: This course addresses the complex issues surrounding families and children with disabilities and transitions across the lifespan, as well as effective collaboration with families and professionals to support inclusion and/or effective early intervention services, educational services, and transition services for students at-risk and students with disabilities.  Emphasis is on successful professional collaboration and effective relationships in educational, transition, and family settings.
Technical and Digital Skills: Familiarity with transition services for students at-risk and students with disabilities
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Maintaining effective relationships in educational, transition, and family settings
Effective communication with families and professionals
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Addressing complex issues surrounding families and children with disabilities
Supporting transitions across the lifespan

courseTitle: Instructional Strategies to Meet Diverse Learning Needs in Math
courseDescription: This course covers instructional strategies necessary to teach mathematics to students with diverse learning needs in elementary and secondary settings. Students will study and apply pedagogy-based research on how learning takes place and strategies for differentiating instruction for the unique needs of diverse learners. Students will address and apply effective research-based methodology and evaluation standards.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing individual learning needs
Developing strategies for unique learning needs
Evaluating effectiveness of instructional strategies

courseTitle: Instructional Strategies for Students Accessing the Adapted Curriculum
courseDescription: This course addresses the characteristics and instructional strategies of students accessing the adapted curriculum. Emphasis is on assessment, program development, academic, and functional skills instruction. This course addresses the needs of individuals with severe and/or profound multiple disabilities. 45 Hour Practicum
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communication with individuals with multiple disabilities
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Special needs assessment analysis
Adapted curriculum problem solving
Functional skills instruction analysis

courseTitle: Characteristics of Students with Visual Impairments
courseDescription: This course provides an overview of the characteristics of and services to persons with visual impairments, including the impact of visual impairment on infants' and children's growth and development, child and adolescent emotional and social development, and family interaction patterns.  It considers the educational, conceptual, psycho-social, and physical implications of a visual impairment.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of services for people with visual impairments
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Empathy towards persons with visual impairments
Effective communication with persons with visual impairments
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the impact of visual impairment on growth and development
Assessing the psycho-social implications of visual impairments
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing services for persons with visual impairments
Leading and guiding families with visually impaired members

courseTitle: Braille Code
courseDescription: This course provides instruction in the development, use, and application of the Braille literary code and its implications for educational/literacy programs for students with visual disabilities.  Students will develop the skills to read and write contracted and uncontracted Braille, while acquiring instructional methodologies for teaching children who are blind to read and write.  Sources of Braille materials for educational purposes are identified.
Technical and Digital Skills: Identifying sources of Braille materials for educational purposes
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Instructional methodologies for teaching Braille to children
Effective communication with visually impaired students
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting teaching approaches to individual student needs
Evaluating the effectiveness of Braille educational programs
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Designing literacy programs for students with visual disabilities

courseTitle: Medical and Educational Implications of Visual Impairments
courseDescription: Provides an introduction to anatomy and physiology of the visual system and the educational implications of visual pathology.  Topics include anatomy of the human eye, normal visual development, pathology of the eye, examination procedures for the identification of visual pathology, and the effects of pathology on visual learning and development. Practicum requires a minimum of 25 hours.
Technical and Digital Skills: Conducting examination procedures for visual pathology
Assessing effects of pathology on visual learning and development
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing visual pathology results
Determining implications of visual pathology on learning and development

courseTitle: Orientation and Mobility
courseDescription: Provides the foundation for understanding the components and essence of orientation and mobility.  Establishes how the need for independent travel in the blind population created the field of O&M.  Explores the philosophy and history of orientation and mobility including cane instruction, dog guides and methods of travel.  Addresses techniques in developing orientation skills and basic mobility instruction.  Motor and concept skill development are emphasized.  Practicum of 45 hours required.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding the components of orientation and mobility
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing orientation skills
Identifying needs for independent travel in blind population
Concept skill development
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Adapting to individual needs and capabilities for independent travel

courseTitle: Curriculum and Assessment of Students with Visual Impairments
courseDescription: Provides students with knowledge and understanding of the educational assessment of students with visual impairments and additional disabilities including deaf-blindness.  Students will practice assessing and planning educational programs for students with visual impairments.  Addresses assessment of technology for students with visual impairments.  Examines determination of learning needs and appropriate learning media, relationship of assessment, IEP development, and placement.  Practicum requires a minimum of 25 hours.
Technical and Digital Skills: Assessment of technology for students with visual impairments
Planning educational programs for students with visual impairments
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Working with students with visual impairments and additional disabilities
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Determining learning needs
Choosing appropriate learning media
Analyzing assessment results

courseTitle: Assistive Technology for Diverse Students
courseDescription: This course provides lectures for pre-service and in-service teachers and related service providers of special populations in the use of assistive technology (AT) devices and services, and augmentative alternative communication (AAC) systems for instructional programs and computer applications. Study will involve compliance with federal and state laws, and national and state standards related to providing assistive technology to diverse students.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of augmentative alternative communication systems
Knowledge of instructional programs and computer applications
Compliance with federal and state laws regarding assistive technology
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying appropriate assistive technology for individual needs
Analyzing the effectiveness of assistive technology in instructional programs
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Adherence to national and state standards
Implementing assistive technology into instructional programs
Leading special populations in the use of assistive technology

courseTitle: Teaching Students with Severe Physical and Sensorimotor Disabilities
courseDescription: This course reviews techniques for working with students who have severe physical and sensorimotor disabilities. Course emphasis is on proper positioning and handling for students with atypical motor/muscle development who function at developmental levels between birth and five years. Practicum of 45 hours required.
Technical and Digital Skills: Techniques for proper positioning and handling of students with severe physical and sensorimotor disabilities
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Empathy and understanding towards students with severe disabilities
Ability to communicate effectively with students at developmental levels between birth and five years
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting teaching techniques to cater to individual student's needs
Analyzing the effectiveness of the teaching techniques used
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Ability to lead and manage students with diverse needs

courseTitle: Teaching Preschoolers With Diverse Abilities
courseDescription: This course prepares students to create high quality learning environments for preschool children (ages 2-5 years) who have diverse strengths and needs. Students will learn how to access curricula and materials, plan for and provide evidence-based instruction, collect data for progress monitoring, and provide adaptations to the environment to support the development of children with and without disabilities. Programming that addresses multiple areas of development, such as social-emotional, communication, motor, and cognition, will be discussed, and students will complete a 10-hour preschool observation.
Technical and Digital Skills: Using digital tools for progress monitoring
Accessing and utilizing online curricula and materials
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and addressing children's diverse communication needs
Building trust and rapport with preschool children
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying and adapting to children's diverse learning needs
Analyzing progress data to adjust teaching strategies
Problem-solving for effective environmental adaptations
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading programming that addresses multiple areas of child development

courseTitle: Developmental Assessment of Young Children with Diverse Abilities
courseDescription: This course prepares students to use recommended practices for assessing the development of young children with diverse abilities, ages birth to 5 years, in home and inclusive/classroom-based settings. Course content and discussions address the knowledge and skills needed by early intervention, early childhood, and early childhood special educators when gathering developmental information to determine a child’s eligibility, plan intervention and educational activities, and monitor progress across time. Practicum of 45 hours required.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of recommended practices for child development assessment
Knowledge of early intervention and special education techniques
Monitoring and tracking child progress over time
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Interacting with children in a home or classroom setting
Adapting communication strategies for children with diverse abilities
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Determining a child’s eligibility for specific programs
Planning effective intervention and educational activities
Analyzing developmental information
Problem-solving in early childhood and special education contexts

courseTitle: Family-Centered Practices in Early Childhood Intervention
courseDescription: This course prepares professionals to partner with families of infants and toddlers (ages birth-three) with developmental delays and disabilities in early intervention programs. Emphasis is placed on the use of family-centered practices that support caregiver and child learning during visits in homes and other community settings. Strategies for collaborating with team members (including the family), writing Individualized Family Service Plans (IFSPs), and providing effective services that facilitate child development during natural family routines and activities will be discussed. Practicum of 45 hours required.
Technical and Digital Skills: Designing effective services for child development
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborating with team members and families
Communicating effectively in home and community settings
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying and addressing developmental delays and disabilities
Adapting strategies for different family routines and activities
Problem-solving in early intervention programs
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading and coordinating visits in homes and community settings

courseTitle: Communication/Language Development/Intervention for Students with Significant Disabilities
courseDescription: This course examines symbolic and non-symbolic communication/language development and acquisition.  Emphasis is on routine-based communication training, communication/language facilitation strategies, augmentative communication systems, and informal/functional communication/language assessment procedures for students in early childhood special education, students with autism, and students with multiple disabilities.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of symbolic and non-symbolic communication
Familiarity with informal/functional communication/language assessment procedures
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to work with students with autism and multiple disabilities
Capability to implement augmentative communication systems
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to assess and analyze communication/language development
Capability to devise strategies for communication/language facilitation
Problem-solving in augmentative communication systems
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and managing individualized communication/language training for students
Ability to lead and implement communication/language intervention strategies
Leadership in managing augmentative communication systems

courseTitle: Field Experience Seminar in Special Education
courseDescription: Explores issues, problems, concerns and processes related to teaching and entering the profession of teaching.  Passing scores on the Virginia Communication and Literacy Assessment (VCLA) and Virginia Reading Assessment (VRA)/ Reading for Virginia Educators (RVE) will be required by the end of the course.
Technical and Digital Skills: Virginia Communication and Literacy Assessment (VCLA) preparation
Virginia Reading Assessment (VRA)/ Reading for Virginia Educators (RVE) preparation
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication in a teaching environment
Building professional relationships in the field of education
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Addressing issues and concerns in the profession of teaching
Analyzing and solving problems related to teaching processes
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizational skills for entering the teaching profession

courseTitle: Teacher Candidate Internship for Special Endorsement
courseDescription: Seven weeks will be completed at the elementary level and seven weeks will be completed at the middle/secondary level. Students enrolled at the graduate level complete 9 credit hours.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Classroom management strategies
Adaptability to different learning styles
Critical thinking for lesson improvement

courseTitle: Topics in Special Education
courseDescription: This course offers selected topics designed to permit small groups of qualified students to work on subjects of mutual interest in the special education field.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of special education regulations and guidelines
Usage of special education software and digital tools
Adaptation of conventional teaching methods for special education
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with students of various learning capabilities
Collaboration with parents and other educators
Empathy and patience in dealing with special education students
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Designing and implementing individualized education plans
Assessing the progress of special education students
Developing strategies to handle behavioral issues
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and managing special education classroom
Leading a team of special education professionals
Coordinating with external agencies for student support

courseTitle: Independent Study in Special Education
courseDescription: Independent study of special topics in special education for undergraduate students.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of assistive technology in special education
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with students with special needs
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing individualized education programs
Adapting educational materials for special needs

courseTitle: Foundations of Special Education: Legal Aspects and Characteristics
courseDescription: The course provides an introduction and overview of the field of special education from the perspective that it is a subsection of general education and that the field is in transition by virtue of philosophical, legislative, and programmatic changes.  Legal aspects, regulatory requirements, and critical analyses of research are addressed. The course includes a broad overview of the characteristics, identification, instructional needs, and accommodation necessary for creating appropriate educational and vocational environments for students with disabilities.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding legislative changes in special education
Knowledge of regulatory requirements in special education
Identification of characteristics of students with disabilities
Creating appropriate educational and vocational environments
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with students with disabilities
Understanding the needs of students with disabilities
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of special education research
Solving issues related to accommodation for students with disabilities
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organization of instructional needs of students with disabilities
Leading transition in special education field

courseTitle: Instructional Design I: Learner Characteristics and Assessment
courseDescription: The intent of this course is to provide pre-service and in-service teachers with: (a) knowledge of the characteristics of K-12 students with learning differences who are accessing either the general curriculum or the adapted curriculum, and (b) the ability to develop knowledge and skill in the selection, administration, scoring and interpretation of standardized/norm-referenced and criterion-referenced assessments for exceptional learners. Administering formal and informal assessment tools for the development of an IEP are emphasized. The use of assessment data to improve evidence-based instruction and student performance is discussed.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of formal and informal assessment tools for IEP development
Interpretation of assessment data to inform evidence-based instruction
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and addressing learning differences in K-12 students
Communication of assessment results and instructional strategies to stakeholders
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification and selection of appropriate assessments for exceptional learners
Analysis and interpretation of assessment results
Adaptation of instruction based on assessment results to improve student performance
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Effective management of diverse learner characteristics

courseTitle: Characteristics and Medical Aspects of Disabling Conditions
courseDescription: This course reviews medical conditions present among individuals with disabilities and implications for classroom instruction.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with individuals with disabilities
Adapting teaching methods to diverse needs
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the effect of disabilities on learning
Creating strategies to overcome learning barriers
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading the adaptation of instructional methods

courseTitle: Students with Diverse Learning Needs in the General Education Classroom
courseDescription: This course introduces general education teachers to the legal aspects and educational needs of at-risk students and those with disabilities.  Emphasis is on characteristics of children with special needs and procedures for effective academic, behavioral, and social integration of these children in the general education classroom.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of legal aspects related to at-risk students and those with disabilities
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with at-risk students and those with disabilities
Social integration techniques for children with special needs
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Procedure development for effective academic and behavioural integration
Analyzing the characteristics and needs of children with special needs
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing educational plans for diverse learners

courseTitle: Classroom and Behavioral Management Techniques for Students with Diverse Needs
courseDescription: This course addresses classroom management techniques and individual interventions based upon behavioral, cognitive, affective, social, and ecological theory and practice. The course focuses on the field of applied behavior analysis, including best practices in the areas of data collection, program selection, program implementation, and data analysis. Positive behavior management, supports, and functional behavioral assessment for students with diverse learning needs will be emphasized.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Implementing supports for students with diverse learning needs
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Functional behavioral assessment
Identifying and addressing behavioral, cognitive, affective, and social issues
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Implementing individual interventions based on various theories and practices

courseTitle: Instructional Design II: Curricular Procedures and Individualized Education Planning
courseDescription: The intent of this course is to provide preservice and in-service teachers with: (a) knowledge of research-based instruction for PreK-12 students with disabilities and those who are gifted; (b) knowledge and skill in using data collection to make decisions about student progress, instruction, program, accommodations and teaching methodology for exceptional learners, and (c) knowledge and skill in planning, developing and implementing individual educational plans and group instruction for diverse exceptional learners who are accessing the general education curriculum and the standards of learning or the adapted education curriculum and the aligned or essentialized standards of learning.
Technical and Digital Skills: Research-based instruction for PreK-12 students with disabilities and those who are gifted
Data collection and analysis for decision making
Planning, developing and implementing individual educational plans and group instruction
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Adapting teaching methodology for exceptional learners
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Decision making based on data collection
Adaptation of teaching methodology based on student progress
Developing and implementing individual educational plans and group instruction for diverse learners
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and developing curriculum for diverse exceptional learners
Leadership in implementing individual educational plans and group instruction
Using data to guide instruction and program decisions

courseTitle: Collaboration and Transitions
courseDescription: This course addresses the complex issues surrounding families and children with disabilities and transitions across the lifespan, as well as effective collaboration with families and professionals to support inclusion and/or effective early intervention services, educational services, and transition services for students at-risk and students with disabilities.  Emphasis is on successful professional collaboration and effective relationships in educational, transition, and family settings.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of disability and transition issues
Familiarity with educational and transition services
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective collaboration with families and professionals
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Addressing complex issues associated with disabilities and transitions
Developing effective interventions and services
Identifying at-risk students
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating educational, transition, and family services

courseTitle: Instructional Strategies to Meet Diverse Learning Needs in Math
courseDescription: This course covers instructional strategies necessary to teach mathematics to students with diverse learning needs in elementary and secondary settings. Students will study and apply pedagogy-based research on how learning takes place and strategies for differentiating instruction for the unique needs of diverse learners. Students will address and apply effective research-based methodology and evaluation standards.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of instructional strategies in mathematics
Differentiation of instruction for diverse learners
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing unique needs of diverse learners
Evaluation of research-based methodology
Evaluation standards

courseTitle: Instructional Strategies for Students Accessing the Adapted Curriculum
courseDescription: This course addresses the characteristics and instructional strategies of students accessing the adapted curriculum. Emphasis is on assessment, program development, academic, and functional skills instruction. This course addresses the needs of individuals with severe and/or profound multiple disabilities. 45 Hour Practicum
Technical and Digital Skills: Program development for students with severe and/or profound multiple disabilities
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communicating with students with severe and/or profound multiple disabilities
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysis of student needs
Adaptation and customization of curriculum
Problem-solving for students with severe and/or profound multiple disabilities
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading a team in program development

courseTitle: Characteristics of Students with Visual Impairments
courseDescription: This course provides an overview of the characteristics of and services to persons with visual impairments, including the impact of visual impairment on infants’ and children’s growth and development, child and adolescent emotional and social development, and family interaction patterns.  Considers the educational, conceptual, psycho-social, and physical implications of a visual impairment.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of impact of visual impairment on development
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing psycho-social implications of visual impairment
Identifying educational implications of visual impairment
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning services for persons with visual impairments

courseTitle: Braille Code
courseDescription: This course provides instruction in the development, use, and application of the Braille literary code and its implications for educational/literacy programs for students with visual disabilities.  Students will develop the skills to read and write contracted and uncontracted Braille, while acquiring instructional methodologies for teaching children who are blind to read and write.  Sources of Braille materials for educational purposes are identified.
Technical and Digital Skills: Identifying sources of Braille materials for educational purposes
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Instructional methodologies for teaching Braille to children who are blind
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of Braille literary code in educational/literacy programs for students with visual disabilities

courseTitle: Medical and Educational Implications of Visual Impairments
courseDescription: Provides an introduction to anatomy and physiology of the visual system and the educational implications of visual pathology.  Topics include anatomy of the human eye, normal visual development, pathology of the eye, examination procedures for the identification of visual pathology, and the effects of pathology on visual learning and development. Practicum of 25 hours required.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of visual system anatomy and physiology
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Explaining educational implications of visual impairments
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying and diagnosing visual pathologies
Analyzing effects of pathology on visual learning and development
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Coordinating and completing required practicum hours

courseTitle: Orientation and Mobility
courseDescription: Provides the foundation for understanding the components and essence of orientation and mobility.  Establishes how the need for independent travel in the blind population created the field of O&M.  Explores the philosophy and history of orientation and mobility including cane instruction, dog guides and methods of travel.  Addresses techniques in developing orientation skills and basic mobility instruction.  Motor and concept skill development are emphasized.  Practicum of 45 hours required.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding needs of the blind population
Adapting teaching methods to individual needs
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing effectiveness of different travel methods
Developing motor and concept skills
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and organizing mobility training sessions

courseTitle: Curriculum and Assessment of Students with Visual Impairments
courseDescription: Provides students with knowledge and understanding of the educational assessment of students with visual impairments and additional disabilities including deaf-blindness.  Students will practice assessing and planning educational programs for students with visual impairments.  Addresses assessment of technology for students with visual impairments.  Examines determination of learning needs and appropriate learning media, relationship of assessment, IEP development, and placement.  Practicum requires a minimum of 25 hours.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of educational assessment of visually impaired students
Assessment of technology for students with visual impairments
Planning educational programs for students with visual impairments
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Working with students with additional disabilities including deaf-blindness
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Determination of learning needs and appropriate learning media
Analyzing assessment results to inform IEP development and placement decisions
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading the development and implementation of IEPs
Organizing and executing a practicum requiring a minimum of 25 hours

courseTitle: Assistive Technology for People with Sensory Impairments
courseDescription: This course is designed for professionals and/or students interested in serving the visually impaired/blind population or hearing impaired/deaf population.  It is designed to heighten the awareness of participants to specific technology and resources available to enhance and improve the ability of individuals with visual and hearing impairments to succeed in school, daily living activities and employment.  Knowledge and awareness components of this course will be delivered via distance education.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of assistive technology for visually impaired
Knowledge of resources for hearing impaired
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Empathy and understanding towards people with sensory impairments
Effective communication with visually and hearing impaired individuals
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to adapt technology to individual needs
Problem-solving for daily living activities and employment challenges
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Ability to manage and coordinate remote learning
Leading initiatives for technology access and inclusion

courseTitle: Assistive Technology for Diverse Students
courseDescription: This course provides lectures for pre-service and in-service teachers, and related service providers of special populations in use of assistive technology (AT) devices and services, and augmentative and alternative communication (AAC) systems for instructional programs and computer applications. Study will involve compliance with federal and state laws, and national and state educational standards related to providing assistive technology to students with diverse learning needs.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of augmentative and alternative communication systems
Understanding of computer applications for special populations
Compliance with federal and state laws related to assistive technology
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Instructional program design for diverse learning needs
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adaptation of assistive technology for diverse learning needs
Analysis of national and state educational standards
Resolution of compliance issues in assistive technology use
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organization of instructional programs using AT and AAC
Implementation of national and state educational standards

courseTitle: Teaching Students with Severe Physical and Sensorimotor Disabilities
courseDescription: This course reviews techniques for working with students who have severe physical and sensorimotor disabilities. Course emphasis is on proper positioning and handling for students with atypical motor/muscle development who function at developmental levels between birth and five years. Practicum of 45 hours required.
Technical and Digital Skills: Techniques for handling students with atypical motor/muscle development
Applying proper positioning for students with physical disabilities
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communicating effectively with students with severe physical and sensorimotor disabilities
Understanding and responding to non-verbal cues
Building trust and rapport with physically challenged students
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting teaching methods to individual student needs
Problem-solving in the context of physical and sensorimotor disabilities
Analyzing students' progress and adjusting teaching techniques accordingly
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading and inspiring students with severe physical and sensorimotor disabilities
Coordinating with other educators and healthcare professionals

courseTitle: Teaching Preschoolers With Diverse Abilities
courseDescription: This course prepares students to create high quality learning environments for preschool children (ages 2-5 years) who have diverse strengths and needs. Students will learn how to access curricula and materials, plan for and provide evidence-based instruction, collect data for progress monitoring, and provide adaptations to the environment to support the development of children with and without disabilities. Programming that addresses multiple areas of development, such as social-emotional, communication, motor, and cognition, will be discussed, and students will complete a 10-hour preschool observation.
Technical and Digital Skills: Accessing and using educational curricula and materials
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Adapting language and instruction for children with diverse needs
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing children's progress
Adapting learning environments for different needs
Planning evidence-based instruction

courseTitle: Developmental Assessment of Young Children with Diverse Abilities
courseDescription: This course prepares students to use recommended practices for assessing the development of young children with diverse abilities, ages birth to 5 years, in home and inclusive/classroom-based settings. Course content and discussions address the knowledge and skills needed by early intervention, early childhood, and early childhood special educators when gathering developmental information to determine a child’s eligibility, plan intervention and educational activities, and monitor progress across time. Practicum of 45 hours required.
Technical and Digital Skills: Ability to monitor progress over time
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to communicate with diverse children
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Determining a child's eligibility for specific educational activities
Planning intervention and educational activities
Analyzing developmental information
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and completing a practicum of 45 hours
Leadership in early childhood education settings

courseTitle: Family-Centered Practices in Early Childhood Intervention
courseDescription: This course prepares professionals to partner with families of infants and toddlers (ages birth-three) with developmental delays and disabilities in early intervention programs. Emphasis is placed on the use of family-centered practices that support caregiver and child learning during visits in homes and other community settings. Strategies for collaborating with team members (including the family), writing Individualized Family Service Plans (IFSPs), and providing effective services that facilitate child development during natural family routines and activities will be discussed. Practicum of 45 hours required.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Partnering with families of infants and toddlers
Providing effective services that facilitate child development
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Implementing strategies for caregiver and child learning during visits
Facilitating child development during natural family routines and activities
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and executing practicum of 45 hours
Leading team collaboration in family-centered practices

courseTitle: Communication/Language Development/Intervention for Students with Significant Disabilities
courseDescription: This course examines symbolic and non-symbolic communication/language development and acquisition.  Emphasis is on routine-based communication training, communication/language facilitation strategies, augmentative communication systems, and informal/functional communication/language assessment procedures for students in early childhood special education, students with autism, and students with multiple disabilities.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communication with students in early childhood special education, students with autism, and students with multiple disabilities
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing symbolic and non-symbolic communication/language
Developing personalized communication training
Adapting communication/language facilitation strategies
Assessing effectiveness of augmentative communication systems

courseTitle: Field Experience Seminar in Special Education
courseDescription: Explores issues, problems, concerns and processes related to teaching and entering the profession of teaching.  Passing scores on the Virginia Communication and Literacy Assessment (VCLA), Praxis II:  Elementary Education Content Test, and Virginia Reading Assessment (VRA)/ Reading for Virginia Educators (RVE) will be required by the end of the course.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of VCLA, Praxis II, and VRA/RVE tests
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with students, parents, and co-workers
Cultural awareness and sensitivity in teaching
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Addressing educational issues and concerns
Developing solutions for teaching-related problems

courseTitle: Teacher Candidate Internship for Special Endorsement
courseDescription: Seven weeks will be completed at the elementary level and seven weeks will be completed at the middle/secondary level.
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting teaching methods for different age groups
Handling classroom challenges
Assessment and evaluation of student progress

courseTitle: Topics in Special Education
courseDescription: This course offers selected topics designed to permit small groups of qualified students to work on subjects of mutual interest in the special education field.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with special needs students
Collaboration with parents and other educators
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting teaching methods to individual student needs
Critical evaluation of special education techniques

courseTitle: English Learners and the Special Education Process
courseDescription: This course will provide students with information regarding the characteristics of English learners with disabilities, the special education law, and the legal requirements for assessment, evaluation, eligibility determination, and program planning. Progress monitoring, annual reviews, and reevaluation of English learners with disability or suspected of a disability also will be reviewed. The role of parents and community will be examined.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of assessment and evaluation methods
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Cultural sensitivity in interacting with English learners
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Eligibility determination for special education
Analytical evaluation of student progress
Problem-solving for program planning
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in managing special education processes

courseTitle: Principles of Language Learning and Assessment of English Learners with Disabilities
courseDescription: This course will provide students with knowledge and skills related to first and second language acquisition, language assessment, response to intervention, program planning, data collection and analysis, and the effective use of interpreters. Special attention is focused upon factors that affect second language acquisition, typical and atypical language development, differentiation for English learners with disabilities, and the bilingual brain.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of first and second language acquisition
Ability to perform response to intervention
Proficiency in data collection and analysis
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Ability to address factors affecting second language acquisition
Effective communication with English learners with disabilities
Understanding of typical and atypical language development
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Ability to differentiate instruction for English learners with disabilities
Problem-solving skills for program planning and response to intervention
Analytical skills in understanding the bilingual brain and language development
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in program planning and intervention
Organizational skills in data collection and analysis

courseTitle: Language, Literature Content for English Learners With Disabilities in Inclusive Settings
courseDescription: This course examines language as the key to learning and the integration of speaking, listening, reading and writing to English learners' (EL) literacy development with a focus on ELs with disabilities. Students will learn phonological and orthographic features of words, factors that influence reading comprehension, how to differentiate instruction, how to teach sentence and paragraph writing, and how to develop academic vocabulary in ELs with disabilities.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding phonological and orthographic features of words
Differentiating instruction for ELs with disabilities
Developing academic vocabulary in ELs with disabilities
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Integrated teaching of speaking, listening, reading and writing to ELs
Adapting communication to accommodate ELs with disabilities
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing factors that influence reading comprehension
Identifying and addressing learning challenges of ELs with disabilities
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and implementing inclusive language and literature lessons
Leading classroom discussions and activities for ELs with disabilities

courseTitle: Instructional Strategies for English Learners with Disabilities
courseDescription: This course details current evidence-based practices to teach English learners with disabilities. Students will learn principles of effective evidence-based instructional strategies and guidelines for selecting them, including the use of technology to teach English learners with disabilities.
Technical and Digital Skills: Adapting technology for learners with disabilities
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with English learners with disabilities
Empathy and understanding towards learners with disabilities
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Selection of appropriate instructional strategies
Assessment of learners' needs
Analyzing effectiveness of instructional strategies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Adapting organizational strategies for learners with disabilities

courseTitle: Characteristics of Students Accessing the General Curriculum
courseDescription: The intent of this course is to provide pre-service and currently licensed teachers with(a) knowledge of the characteristics of students with disabilities who are accessing the general curriculum, K-12, including, but not limited to learning disabilities, emotional disabilities, and intellectual disabilities; (b) the ability to recognize etiologies, underlying factors, and contributing conditions that impact student learning, and (c) the cultural impact of disabling conditions.
Technical and Digital Skills: Identifying contributing conditions impacting student learning
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with students with disabilities
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing the effect of disabling conditions on student learning
Formulating strategies for students with disabilities accessing general curriculum

courseTitle: Instructional Strategies for Students Accessing the General Education Curriculum
courseDescription: This course emphasizes effective research-based instructional strategies for teaching students with mild/moderate disabilities in grades K-12 who are accessing the general education curriculum. Practicum of 45 hours in middle/secondary-level setting is required.
Technical and Digital Skills: Adapting general curriculum for students with disabilities
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communication with students with mild/moderate disabilities
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing student needs
Developing effective learning strategies

courseTitle: Human Growth and Development
courseDescription: This course is designed to give a thorough overview of human development from birth through adolescence and to develop an understanding of what impact physical, social, emotional, and intellectual development may have on the student, the learning environment, and instructional decisions. This course provides an advanced overview of current research and theory in human growth and development and their applications to the classroom. Throughout the course, issues of diversity as it applies to economic, social, racial, ethnic, and religious characteristics will be explored; developmental issues related to giftedness or disability and the impact of family disruptions, child abuse, and substance abuse will be addressed within the context of each topic.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Recognizing and addressing signs of child abuse or substance abuse
Communicating effectively with individuals of different economic, social, racial, ethnic, and religious backgrounds
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Understanding and applying theories of human growth and development
Assessing the impact of various factors on human development
Addressing developmental issues related to giftedness or disability
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading classroom applications of current research and theory in human growth and development

courseTitle: Advanced Classroom and Behavior Management Techniques for Students with Diverse Needs
courseDescription: This course addresses classroom management techniques and individual interventions based upon behavioral, cognitive, affective, social, and ecological theory and practice. The course focuses on the field of applied behavior analysis, including best practices in the areas of data collection, program selection, program implementation, and data analysis. Positive behavior management, supports, and functional behavioral assessment for students with diverse learning needs will be emphasized.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Implementing support for students with diverse learning needs
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Application of behavioral, cognitive, affective, social, and ecological theories in classroom management
Identifying appropriate interventions for individual students

courseTitle: Advanced Instructional Design I: Learner Characteristics and Assessment
courseDescription: The intent of this course is to provide pre-service and in-service teachers with: (a) knowledge of the characteristics of K-12 students with learning differences who are accessing either the general curriculum or the adapted curriculum and (b) the ability to develop knowledge and skill in the selection, administration, scoring and interpretation of standardized/norm-referenced and criterion-referenced assessments for exceptional learners. Administering formal and informal assessment tools for the development of an IEP are emphasized. The use of assessment data to improve evidence-based instruction and student performance is discussed. Practicum of 45 hours required.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of assessment data to improve instruction
Application of formal and informal assessment tools
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and accommodating learning differences in K-12 students
Interpreting assessment results for exceptional learners
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Selection of appropriate assessment strategies
Scoring and interpretation of assessment results
Utilizing assessment data to improve student performance
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Development and execution of specialized curriculum for diverse learners

courseTitle: Advanced Foundations of Special Education: Legal Aspects and Characteristics
courseDescription: The course provides an introduction and overview of the field of special education from the perspective that it is a subsection of general education and that the field is in transition by virtue of philosophical, legislative, and programmatic changes.  Legal aspects, regulatory requirements, and critical analyses of research are addressed. The course includes a broad overview of the characteristics, identification, instructional needs, and accommodation necessary for creating appropriate educational and vocational environments for students with disabilities.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of educational law and regulations
Creation of suitable educational and vocational environments
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with individuals with disabilities
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Critical analysis of legislative and programmatic changes
Development of personalized educational plans
Problem-solving for accommodation challenges
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Compliance with educational laws and regulations

courseTitle: Effective Interventions for Children and Youth with Challenging Behavior
courseDescription: Students with challenging behavior pose a tremendous challenge to school personnel.  Along with the growing incidence of behavior problems, there has been a dramatic increase in the number of research-supported interventions.  Emphasis is on assessment of the structural and functional properties of problem behavior to facilitate development of interventions that match the nature and severity of the problem behavior.  The course focuses on gaining knowledge of the likely source(s) of challenging behavior, including various strategies to document the environmental determinants of the behavior, establishment of school-wide, classroom-level, and student-specific intervention programs and ways to document the outcome of those interventions.  Attention is given to adult- as well as peer-mediated intervention options for problem behavior  reduction/replacement among children and youth from diverse backgrounds and across categories of exceptionality. Practicum of 45 hours required.
Technical and Digital Skills: Assessment of structural and functional properties of problem behavior
Documentation of environmental determinants of behavior
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Working with students from diverse backgrounds and categories of exceptionality
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Development of interventions that match the nature and severity of the problem behavior
Identification of the likely sources of challenging behavior
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Management of school-wide, classroom-level, and student-specific intervention programs

courseTitle: Advanced Collaboration and Transitions
courseDescription: This course addresses the complex issues surrounding families and children with disabilities and transitions across the lifespan, as well as effective collaboration with families and professionals to support inclusion and/or effective early intervention services, educational services, and transition services for students at-risk and students with disabilities.  Emphasis is on successful professional collaboration and effective relationships in educational, transition, and family settings.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective collaboration with families and professionals
Building effective relationships in educational, transition, and family settings
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Addressing complex issues surrounding families and children with disabilities
Supporting inclusion for students at-risk and students with disabilities

courseTitle: Adv Instructional Design II: Curriculum Procedures and Individualized Education Planning
courseDescription: The intent of this course is to provide preservice and in-service teachers with: (a) knowledge of research-based instruction for PreK-12 students with disabilities and those who are gifted; (b) knowledge and skill in using data collection to make decisions about student progress, instruction, program, accommodations and teaching methodology for exceptional learners, and (c) knowledge and skill in planning, developing and implementing individual educational plans and group instruction for diverse exceptional learners who are accessing the general education curriculum and the standards of learning or the adapted education curriculum and the aligned or essentialized standards of learning. Practicum of 45 hours required.
Technical and Digital Skills: Instructional design for PreK-12 students with disabilities
Instructional design for PreK-12 students who are gifted
Data collection for assessment and decision-making
Planning, developing and implementing individual educational plans
Planning, developing and implementing group instruction for diverse exceptional learners
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Data analysis for student progress assessment
Problem-solving for exceptional learners' educational needs
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading group instruction for diverse exceptional learners

courseTitle: Characteristics of Students with Autism Spectrum Disorders
courseDescription: This course includes a review of characteristics, etiology, prevalence, and perspectives of students with autism spectrum disorders.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of prevalence and etiology of autism
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Collaborative interaction with parents and other educators
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing characteristics of autism
Evaluating perspectives on autism
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Tailoring educational strategies to individual needs

courseTitle: Advanced Procedures in Reading and Writing for Students with Diverse Learning Needs
courseDescription: This course provides the professional educator with a variety of educational procedures for students with disabilities in reading and writing, including diagnostic assessment, causal nature of the disability, and evidence-based instructional strategies. Application of evidence-based practices for assessing and teaching students with disabilities who have severe deficits in reading and writing is emphasized.
Technical and Digital Skills: Implementation of evidence-based instructional strategies in reading and writing
Understanding and identification of the causal nature of learning disabilities
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Instructional communication for students with disabilities
Differentiated instruction for diverse learning needs
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying severe deficits in reading and writing
Application of evidence-based practices for assessment and instruction
Problem solving for learning disability related issues
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Organizing and managing individualized education plans
Leading instructional strategies for students with disabilities

courseTitle: Instructional Strategies for Students with Autism Spectrum Disorders
courseDescription: This course includes a review of intervention strategies for students with autism spectrum disorders. Practicum of 45 hours required.
Technical and Digital Skills: Use of digital tools for student engagement
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Empathy and understanding towards students with autism
Collaborative work with parents and other educators
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing tailored intervention strategies
Analyzing student behavior and progress
Problem-solving for student-specific issues

courseTitle: Instructional Strategies for Students Accessing the Adapted Curriculum
courseDescription: This course addresses the characteristics and instructional strategies of students accessing the adapted curriculum. Emphasis is on assessment, program development, academic, and functional skills instruction. This course addresses the needs of individuals with severe and/or profound multiple disabilities. Practicum of 45 hours required.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Understanding and addressing the needs of individuals with severe and/or profound multiple disabilities
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting and applying instructional strategies to cater to individual needs
Assessing and interpreting student progress
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing and completing a practicum of 45 hours
Designing and implementing individualized academic programs

courseTitle: Teaching Preschoolers with Disabilities
courseDescription: This course is designed to prepare students in curricula, materials and methods of instruction for preschool-aged (2 to 6 years) children with special needs.  Programming for self-help,  social, language, motor, and cognitive development are addressed.  Data collection, program organization, and classroom planning are also covered. Practicum of 45 hours required.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Instruction methods for children with special needs
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Addressing cognitive development issues
Addressing motor development issues
Analyzing and adjusting teaching methods based on data

courseTitle: Developmental Assessment of Young Children with Diverse Abilities
courseDescription: This course prepares students to use recommended practices for assessing the development of young children with diverse abilities, ages birth to 5 years, in home and inclusive/classroom-based settings. Course content and discussions address the knowledge and skills needed by early intervention, early childhood, and early childhood special educators when gathering developmental information to determine a child’s eligibility, plan intervention and educational activities, and monitor progress across time. Practicum of 45 hours required.
Technical and Digital Skills: Implementation of recommended practices for assessing development
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with children of diverse abilities
Collaborative planning of intervention and educational activities
Interacting with families in home and classroom-based settings
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Determining a child’s eligibility for intervention
Analyzing developmental information
Adapting assessments according to child's needs
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Planning and coordinating early intervention strategies

courseTitle: Teaching Students with Severe Physical and Sensorimotor Disabilities
courseDescription: This course reviews techniques for working with students who have severe physical and sensorimotor disabilities. Emphasis is on proper positioning and handling for students with atypical motor/muscle development who function at developmental levels between birth and five years. Practicum of 45 hours required.
Technical and Digital Skills: Techniques for handling atypical motor/muscle development
Knowledge of severe physical and sensorimotor disabilities
Understanding of developmental levels between birth and five years
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communicating effectively with students with severe disabilities
Adapting communication methods for individual needs
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identifying individual student needs
Adapting techniques for individual students
Assessing the effectiveness of positioning and handling techniques

courseTitle: Cortical and Cerebral Visual Impairment
courseDescription: This class will provide an overview of cortical visual impairment (CVI) including causes, visual characteristics, assessments, and interventions for students with CVI.
Technical and Digital Skills: Knowledge of assessment techniques for CVI
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analysing causes of CVI
Assessing visual characteristics of students with CVI
Developing tailored interventions based on assessments
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading a team in implementing interventions

courseTitle: Infant/Family Intervention and Teamwork
courseDescription: This course prepares professionals from cross-discipline backgrounds to serve families with children who are at-risk and disabled from birth through age three.  Emphasis is place on the development of the individualized family service plan (IFSP), procedures, materials and curriculum for this population. A family-centered approach is stressed. Practicum of 45 hours required.
Technical and Digital Skills: Development of individualized family service plan (IFSP)
Understanding of procedures, materials and curriculum for at-risk and disabled children
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Identification of at-risk and disabled children
Implementation of intervention strategies
Adapting plans and procedures to individual family needs

courseTitle: Teaching Methods for Students with Visual Impairments
courseDescription: This course emphasizes methods of teaching compensatory skills, the core curriculum, and technology for use by students who are blind and visually impaired.  It addresses curriculum development, adaptations, and teaching methodology for individuals with visual impairments.  In addition, it provides information on adaptations within various educational programs and adaptation of general education classroom materials and procedures for use with blind and low vision children and youth.
Technical and Digital Skills: Adapting general education classroom materials for use with blind and visually impaired students
Using technology for students who are blind and visually impaired
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Communicating effectively with blind and visually impaired students
Building rapport with students with visual impairments
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Developing curriculum for visually impaired students
Creating adaptations within various educational programs
Problem-solving for educational challenges faced by visually impaired students
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leading educational programs for visually impaired students
Organizing and adapting classroom procedures for visually impaired students

courseTitle: Braille Reading and Writing
courseDescription: Provides instruction on transcription of advanced braille codes, including: mathematics (UEB and Nemeth) music, foreign language, and other specialized codes.  Introduces techniques for teaching skills in each code.  Explores technology tools used to create braille and tactile materials in addition to other assistive technologies used for instruction in STEM content. Practicum requires a minimum of 15 hours.
Technical and Digital Skills: Usage of technology tools for creation of braille and tactile materials
Understanding of assistive technologies for STEM instruction
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Teaching techniques for different braille codes
Ability to communicate complex concepts in a simple, understandable manner
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Adapting teaching methods based on individual learner's needs
Problem-solving technical issues with braille technology tools

courseTitle: Applied Behavior Analysis: Concepts and Principles
courseDescription: This course focuses on the concepts and principles of applied behavior analysis; identification of factors that increase or decrease the probability of behavior under specific circumstances.
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication of behavioral analysis results
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing behavior under specific circumstances
Identifying factors that influence behavior

courseTitle: Applied Behavior Analysis: Empirical Bases
courseDescription: Applications of single-case experimental research designs to the analysis of behavior with emphasis on measurement, visual display of data, and interpretation of results.
Technical and Digital Skills: Application of single-case experimental research designs
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Measurement and quantification of behavior
Problem-solving in experimental design
Analytical interpretation of behavioral data

courseTitle: Ethics and Professional Conduct for Behavior Analysts
courseDescription: This course provides a basis in Virginia Behavior Analyst Licensure law, the Behavior Analyst Certification Board’s Ethics Code for Behavior Analysts, disciplinary systems, and professional conduct consistent with the practice of applied behavior analysis.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of Virginia Behavior Analyst Licensure law
Proficiency in interpreting the Behavior Analyst Certification Board’s Ethics Code
Knowledge of disciplinary systems relevant to behavior analysis
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing ethical dilemmas
Application of licensure law and ethics code to real-world scenarios
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Leadership in adhering to ethical guidelines

courseTitle: Applied Behavior Analysis: Assessments and Interventions
courseDescription: Identification and assessment of problem behavior and socially-appropriate behaviors, implementation of function-based intervention plans, and design of environments to prevent and address problem behavior.
Technical and Digital Skills: Designing environments to prevent and address problem behavior
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Demonstrating empathy and understanding in behavior assessment
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Problem behavior analysis
Analyzing the effectiveness of intervention strategies
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing environments to promote positive behavior

courseTitle: Applied Behavior Analysis: Applications
courseDescription: Application of concepts and principles of behavior analysis to a wide range of populations, settings, and behaviors within the context of more sophisticated clinical and professional issues and environments.
Technical and Digital Skills: Adapting behavior analysis techniques for diverse settings and populations
Problem-Solving and Analytical Skills: Analyzing behavioral patterns
Developing solutions for behavioral issues
Critical assessment of clinical issues
Organizational and Leadership Skills: Managing professional issues in clinical settings

courseTitle: Applied Behavior Analysis: Verbal Behavior
courseDescription: B.F. Skinner's analysis of verbal behavior and the design, development, and implementation of curriculum, language and communication interventions for individuals with language delays.
Technical and Digital Skills: Understanding of B.F. Skinner's analysis of verbal behavior
Developing curriculum for individuals with language delays
Interpersonal and Communication Skills: Effective communication with individuals with language delays
